questions.question_text:
Due to new regulations, a company has decided to institute an organizational vulnerability management program and assign the function to the security team.
Which of the following frameworks would BEST support the program? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: This should be NIST and ITIL.
Scored a 880 on this exam and had this question. The correct answer is ISO 27000 and NIST. ITIL is a framework for IT Service Management. Nothing to do with vulnerabilities.

Selected Answer: BD
NIST Special Publications (e.g., NIST SP 800-40) offer comprehensive guidance on vulnerability management. 

ISO 27001 outlines how to build and maintain an Information Security Management System (ISMS), which includes vulnerability management.

It's definitely not A or E, so that leaves B, C & D. NIST is definitely a right answer, but I have doubts between ISO and ITIL... .

https://advisera.com/27001academy/blog/2016/03/07/iso-27001-vs-itil-similarities-and-differences

This should be NIST and ISO 27000 series. See ISO 27001 control A.12.6.1 for managing vulnerabilities which is focused on Timely identification of vulnerabilities, Assessment of organizationâ€™s exposure to a vulnerability, Proper measures considering the associated risks.

comments.content: ISO 27k is a set of standards not a framework. ITIL and NIST best fit the question as they are frameworks

discussion.content: Agree that OWASP is wrong, but if NIST is correct then ISO 27000 should be too.
Agreed with Dan. OWASP is for web apps as KC confirmed.
Agree with Dan, OWASP is focused on web apps, not an entire security framework.

comments.content: I agree. When I think of traditional training methods, the methods that come to mind are classroom training, online training, and computer based training programs.

discussion.content: Classroom training can be considered a traditional training method. I would go with letter B on this one.
Agree with A. Classroom training might be traditional but with the reward system after getting a perfect score will push the students to learn making this the most effective

The answer is C.

A. That's just a standard training session.
B. Sending fake phishing mails is A-OKAY, but asking them to send PII is not.
C. That's the right one because you're including everyone in the conversation, instead of forcing them to listen to someone droning on about Social Engineering tactics.
D. There are inherent security risks related to this option.

comments.content: which side are you on? test taker or the maker?

choices.A: Classroom training on the dangers of social media followed by a test and gift certificates for any employee getting a perfect score.
choices.C: A poster contest to raise awareness of PII and asking employees to provide examples of data breaches and consequences
choices.B: Simulated phishing emails asking employees to reply to the email with their updated phone number and office location
choices.D: USB drives randomly placed inside and outside the organization that contain a pop-up warning to any users who plug the drive into their computer

questions.question_text: After reading about data breaches at a competing company, senior leaders in an organization have grown increasingly concerned about social engineering attacks. They want to increase awareness among staff regarding this threat, but do not want to use traditional training methods because they regard these methods as ineffective. Which of the following approaches would BEST meet the requirements?

discussion.content: This one tripped me up really bad. I completely forgot that how mac addresses were structured. the first half of the mac is the manufacturer code and the second half IDs the NIC. The Workshop AP is the only one that is completely different than the rest. They went back to A+ material for this question
easy to spot -- all AP-xxxx devices (1.10 to 1.14) should begin with the same MAC address. The correct answer clearly has a completely different MAC
NIST and ISO 27000 series

Policies form the basis of every strong information security program. A solid policy framework consists of policies, standards, procedures, and guidelines that work together to describe the security control environment of an organization. In addition to complying with internally developed policies, organizations often must comply with externally imposed compliance obligations. Security frameworks, such as the NIST Cybersecurity Framework and ISO 27001, provide a common structure for security programs based on accepted industry best practices. Organizations should implement and test security controls to achieve security control objectives that are developed based on the business and technical environment of the organization.
This question appears earlier on in this same question bank (it is a duplicate), and the discussion landed on NIST and ITIL as the answer.

comments.content: I need to post a comment against the duplicate question. Checked ITIL Security Management, there is a sub-process called "Evaluate", which includes self-assessment, defined as "Examine implemented security agreements. The result of this process is self-assessment documents.". This would include vulnerability management, but it is presented at such a vague and high level that it would not be much use in helping direct the establishment of a vuln mgmt program. Bearing in mind the debate about whether ISO can be considered a framework (and we are talking semantics here!), I would also lean towards NIST and COBIT.
Definitely COBIT. COBIT 5 for Information Security is the reference, available from ISACA.
Thanks mate. May I know what is the title of that book?

discussion.content: Nope, my book from Pearson explicitly states COBIT and NIST are for vuln mgmt. This is a mistake

questions.question_text:
Due to new regulations, a company has decided to institute an organizational vulnerability management program and assign the function to the security team.
Which of the following frameworks would BEST support the program? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
the correct is: C- XSS
reference:
https://owasp.org/www-community/attacks/xss/

comments.content: Upvote! this is XSS straight from OWASP as linked above.

discussion.content: Says attacks w/ an s, aka plural. Maybe on exam it asks for multiple? If this is the case, I'm thinking XSS + Session Hijacking. Not SQL because the query is never used.
technically, an SQL injection attack is taking place inside an XSS?

For those who have lingering doubts about this:

A. MITM: Absolutely not.
B. Session hijacking: Potentially this could be the follow-up attack once the attacker has gathered the cookie from the user.
C. XSS: Yes. This is a typical example of a cookie grabber attack.
D. Privilege escalation: Absolutely not.
E. SQL injection: The SQL statement is a red herring. This is nothing more than a variable called "query" being filled up with an SQL statement. It's not being executed anywhere, nor is it in any way related to an SQL injection.

Here's an additional resource that may help you understand how XSS cookie grabber attacks work: https://medium.com/@laur.telliskivi/pentesting-basics-cookie-grabber-xss-8b672e4738b2
I think this one shoule be session hijacking. Why would anyone wants to willingly send one's cookie as a parameter to a website?

comments.content: why session hijacking? Select * from users is already a give away for sql injection

discussion.content: Shouldn't be Session hijacking ?
